speaker: parent
content: One winter morning, Peter woke up and looked out the window. Snow had fallen during the night. It covered everything as far as he could see. After breakfast, he put on his snowsuit and ran outside. Snow was piled up very high along the street to make a path for walking.

speaker: parent
content: Go ahead.

speaker: parent
content: Crunch, crunch, crunch. His feet sank into the snow. He walked with his toes pointing out like this. He walked with his toe pointing in, like that. Then he dragged his feet slowly to make tracks. And he found something sticking out of the snow that made a new track. It was a stick. A stick that was just right for smacking a snow covered tree. And down fell the snow. Plop on top of Peter's head.

speaker: parent
content: He thought it would be fun to join the big boys in their snowball fight, but he knew he wasn't old enough. Not yet. So he made a smiling snowman and he made angels. He pretended he was a mountain climber. He climbed up a great big tall heaping mountain of snow and slid all the way down. He picked up a handful of snow and another and still another. He packed it round and firm and put the snowball in his pocket for tomorrow. Then he went in his warm house.

speaker: parent
content: He told his mother all about his adventures while she took off his wet socks. And he though and thought and thought about them. Before he got into bed, he looked in his pocket. His pocket was empty. The snowball wasn't there. He felt very sad.

speaker: child
content: Sad.

speaker: parent
content: Sad.

speaker: child
content: Sad.

speaker: parent
content: While he slept, he dreamed that the sun had melted all the snow away. Then when he woke up, his dream was gone. Snow was still everywhere. New snow was falling. After breakfast, he called to his friend from across the hall and they went out together into this deep, deep snow.

speaker: parent
content: And that's it.

speaker: parent
content: The Little Engine that Could.

speaker: parent
content: Chug. Chug. Chug. Puff. Puff. Puff. Ding dong. Ding dong. The little train rumbled over the tracks. She was a happy little train for she had such a jolly load to carry. Her cars were filled full of good things for boys and girls.

speaker: parent
content: There were toy animals. Giraffes, with long necks. Teddy bears, with almost no necks at all. [crosstalk 00:05:11] and even a baby elephant. Then there were dolls. Dolls with blue eyes and yellow curls. Dolls with brown eyes and brown bobbed heads and the funniest little toy clown you've ever saw.

speaker: parent
content: And there were cars full of toy engines. Airplanes, tops, jack knives, picture puzzles, books and every kind of thing boy or girls could want. But that was not all. Some of the cars were filled all sorts of good things for boys and girls to eat. Big golden oranges, red sheet apples, bottles of creamy milk for their breakfast, fresh spinach for their dinners, peppermint drops and lollipops for after [inaudible 00:06:17].

speaker: parent
content: The little train was carrying all these wonderful things to the little boys and girls on the other side of the mountain. She puffed along merrily.

speaker: parent

speaker: parent
content: Then all of a sudden she stopped with a jerk. She simply could not go another inch. She tried and she tried but her wheels would not turn. What were all those good little boys and girls on the other side of the mountain going to do without the wonderful toys to play with and the good food to eat?
question: What were all those good little boys and girls on the other side of the mountain going to do without the wonderful toys to play with and the good food to eat

speaker: parent
content: "Here comes a shiny new engine," said the funny little clown who jumped out of the train. "Let's ask him to help us."

speaker: parent
content: So all the dolls and toys cried out together. "Please shiny new engine. Won't you please pull our train over the mountain. Our engine has broken down and the good boys and the girls on the other side won't have any toys to play with or good food to eat unless you help us."

speaker: parent
content: But the shiny new engine snorted. "I pull you? I'm no passenger engine. I have just carried a fine, big train over the mountain with more cars than you've ever dreamed of. My train had sleeping cars, comfortable [inaudible 00:07:58] and dining carts where waiters bring whatever hungry people want to eat. The parlor cars in which people sit in, soft arm chairs and look out of big plate glass windows. I pull the likes of you, indeed not!"

speaker: parent
content: And off he steamed to the roundhouse where engines live when they are not busy. How sad the little train and all the dolls and toys felt. But the big strong engine billowed, "I'm a freight engine. I've just pulled a big train loaded with big machines over the mountain. These machines print books and papers for grownups to read. I'm a very important engine, indeed. I won't pull the likes of you."

speaker: parent

"The freight engine is not the only one in world. Here comes another. He looks very old and tired. But our train is so little perhaps he can help us."

speaker: parent

"Won't you please pull our train over the mountain? Our engine has broken down and the boys and girls on the other side won't have any toys to play with or good food to eat unless you help us."

speaker: parent
content: But the rusty old engine said "I'm so tired. I must rest my weary wheels. I can not pull even so a little train as yours over the mountain. I can not, I can not, I can not." And off her rumbled to the roundhouse, chugging "I can not, I can not, I can not."

speaker: parent
content: The little clown called out, "Here is another engine coming! A little blue engine, a very little one. Maybe she will help us."

speaker: parent
content: The very little engine came chug chugging merrily along when she saw the toy clown's flag. She stopped quickly. "What is the matter, my friends?" She asked kindly.

speaker: parent
content: "Oh little blue engine," cried the dolls and the toys. "Will you pull us over the mountain? Our engine has broken down and the good boys and the girls on the other side won't have any toys to play with or good food to eat unless you help us. Please help. Please help us, little blue engine."

speaker: parent
content: "I'm not very big," said the little engine. "They use me only for switching trains in the yard. I have never been over the mountain."

speaker: parent
content: "But we must get over the mountain before the children awake." Said all the dolls and the toys. The very little engine looked up and saw the tears in the dolls eyes and then when she thought of the good little boys and girls on the other side of the mountain who would not have any toys or good food unless she helped. Then she said, "I think I can. I think I can. I think I can." Then she hitched herself to the little train.

speaker: parent
content: Once there was a boy named Nikki who wanted his new mittens made from wool as white as snow. [inaudible 00:15:31] At first his [crosstalk 00:15:33] grandmother, Bubba, did not want to knit white mittens. If you drop one in the snow, you'll never find it.

speaker: child
content: I'm sure he will.

speaker: parent
content: But Nikki wanted snow white mittens. Finally Bubba made them. After she finished, she said "When you come home, first I will look to see if you're safe and sound. But then I will look to see if you still have your snow white mittens."

speaker: parent
content: So off Nikki went and it wasn't long until one of his new mittens dropped in the snow and it was left behind. A mole tired from tunneling along discovered the mitten and burrowed inside. It was cozy and warm and just the right size so he decided to stay. A snowshoe...

speaker: child
content: Hare.

speaker: parent
content: A snowshoe rabbit came hopping out...

speaker: parent
content: Hopping by. He stopped for a moment to admire his winter coat. It was then that he saw the mitten and he wiggled in. At first the mole didn't think there was room for both of them but when he saw the rabbits big kickers he moved over. Next a [crosstalk 00:17:11] hedgehog snuffling along. Having spent the day looking under with leaves for things to eat, he decided to move into the mitten and warm himself. The mole and the rabbit were bumped and jolsted but not being one to argue with someone covered with prickles, they made room.

speaker: parent
content: As soon as the hedgehog disappeared in the mitten, a big owl attracted by the commotion swooped down. When he decided to move in also...

content: A great bear lumbered by. He spied the mitten all lumped up but not being one to be left out in the cold, he began to nose his way in. The animals were packed in as tightly as can be but what animal would argue with a bear.
